content:
In school I tried to play basketball and volleyball and failed pretty miserably. Despite being tall, I was simply not aggressive.
I have found out that I am aggressive in areas like making art and entertaining people. If I can make something beautiful or help someone I will be extremely forceful about it. I think many artists are this way.

content:
Last thing last night, we were having a discussion about academic ethics.

It went like this:

If you are asked to review a journal article which is about a bit of code (say on GitHub), should you - as the reviewer - raise issues or pull requests?

My position was/is that if a reviewer actively engages in a pull request, that's a COI.

Thoughts? #academia #coding #rstats

content: I promise not to ask more than a few times a year, but: if you know of any recently-published High-Trust Trad adventures, I want to know about them so I can (A) Roll around on them gleefully in kind of a pervy way (B) read them, study them, and GM them for my gaming groups and (C) promote them at every opportunity. If you're unclear on what I'm looking for, click this handsome #HTTRPG hashtag. Many thanks for any recommendations.

content: Every time I think 'I should get a #bike and #cycle instead of hanging about waiting for Dublin bus', I see some horrifying video of how Irish drivers treat cyclists and rapidly change that idea. I don't want conflict as part of my commute, and even if one ran over me intentionally they'd likely get not even a wee smack from the Irish courts, so I'd have to avenge my death by haunting the fecker.

content:
Takeaways from the Splinter session: Flying habits of Astronomers:
1. Institutional support for CO2-poor travel needed !
2. For larger size meetings, remote participation should be favoured.
3. Travel more important for younger researchers than for others.

account.note: Astronomy students, educators, & scientists addressing the climate crisis from the astronomical perspective. Join the conversation with #Astro4Earth!

content: People might say ‚Äútake that back!‚Äù and we might say ‚ÄúOK, I take it back‚Äù but in fact, you can‚Äôt take words back once you‚Äôve said them. There are things it‚Äôs not OK to say, and things will never be the same no matter how sincerely you apologize. Things might be OK, but they will be different.
